author: bwana
title: Cardano Linux Distro for SBCs
description: Terceiros são vulnerabilidades. Executar um nó é a resposta, mas compromete os recursos em seu computador. Os nós de SBC são a resposta.

f6_assessments.q0:
Creating a GNU/Linux distro specially for running a Cardano node with associated tools on an SBC (Single Board Computer - we wish this acronym had been defined) could be useful to easily deploy a Cardano node software on the many existing Android devices available everywhere on the planet.
Unfortunately this is a draft proposal of only 66 words with just a YouTube Interview form 1.5 years ago of one of the proposer talking about running a Cardano node successfully on an Android Device.

Given the very low amount of information given I can only give 2 stars to this proposal which probably should have been withdrawn.
f6_assessments.q1:
Some relevant experience is stated as well as a GitHub profile of one of the proposer showcasing relevant related work but with low activity.
It would have been useful to know what is the roles of the 2 proposers, the one in the interview seems to be Mike, no information about Aaron.
There is not enough information provided to assess the proposers experience properly. No plan at all is given in this 66 words proposal, there is only 1 star to be given.
f6_assessments.q2:
There is no auditable information given at all (no plan, no KPI, no success definition).
Moreover such an endeavor would require a proper assessment of the state of SBCs since the Cardano node is using an increasing amount of resources and SBCs, to my knowledge, are not yet powerful enough to cope with this increase.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposer has managed to run the shelly cardano node on an android phone. The stated problem is the need to avoid third party applications because they're a potential security risk and can never be as safe as a node that can verify all transactions. The author could have done a better job explaining the implications of what he has done which is epic by itself. There are not key metrics to speak of. The proposal can scale very easily if what the proposer has done is made into an application that you can just install on your phone and have it work for you. Unfortunately there are a lot of things missing from the proposal like key metrics, budget breakdown, any timeline, deffinition of success and a detailed explatation along to name the biggest ones.  I'm concerned that this wouldn't be voted in, even though as a developer I really want it to be.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer has provided a github, which is related in some way with https://lowski.dev/ site and https://twitter.com/lowskidev. I'm not sure if this is a person or a company because no infromation was left in the proposal that would help verify the identity and credentials of the proposer. I understand people value their privacy, but that has to be measure agains the credability you get when you stand with your name behind your proposal. There's no mention of team members and I was left with the impression that this was a fun experiment, but not something they want to work on seriously. There is a budget but no breakdown of costs or hourly rates or any other breakdown. There is no timetable or deffinition of success to speak of. There is no plan for future implementation and integration, just the idea of publishing an android application that you can use. There are no resources described to bring the project to fruition. The technical aspects of the proposal were mentioned in the video, but they were little mentioned to make something out of them.  My suggestion for this proposal is to come back strong in the next funding round with a proper proposal. I'm looking forward to it. Good luck!
f6_assessments.q2: The tracability for this project is very hard since no linkes or future plans were given.   No roadmaps, metrics or understandable description provided for community members to follow.   I'm hoping for this proposal to end up better in the next round!

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is about building an open-source Linux distro with tools to host and interact with a local Cardano node running on an SBC through local dapps or web interface. The problem statement is not explained in detail [why "SBC nodes are the answer" to  "Third parties are vulnerabilities" instead of "Running a node" ?]. Because this proposal is incomplete, so the solution is very abstract, however, I think it's worth trying for completing in the following fund. Based on the given information, I disagree with this proposal's impact, and would give it a score of 2.
f6_assessments.q1: This proposer's relevant experiences show that this team is quite suitable to implement this kind of work, however, there is no proof/link for verification. As a result, based on the given information, I disagree with this proposal's feasible, and would give it a score of 2.
f6_assessments.q2: Since this proposal is not completed. Therefore, auditability can't be guaranteed. My only advice would be: the proposer needs to ensure that the following components are fully met: (i) Goals, target; (2) milestones (integrated with measurable KPIs/metrics); (3) Budget breakdown; (4) Risk and mitigation. Based on the given information, I strongly disagree with this proposal's auditability, and would give it a score of 1.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal does effectively address open source by potentially providing a low cost solution to engage developers to interact with the Cardano ecosystem. I would suggest that you provide an example of how you plan to get this technology to a wider audience.
f6_assessments.q1: The developers involved have provided reasonable contact information and means of contact. There needs to be some kind of plan to implement the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: There is no break down of how funds will be utilized. There's no research into cost of materials or a road map to produce a prototype.

solution: Uma distribuição Linux de código aberto com ferramentas para hospedar e interagir com um nó Cardano local rodando em um SBC através de dapps locais ou interface web.
experience: Desenvolveu uma distribuição Linux similar para redes EVM suportando clientes Geth, Parity e Mantis com nós de hardware dedicados em 2019.
